awd_titl_txt: AGEP National Research Conference 2020: Sustaining, Institutionalizing and Scaling AGEP Alliance Models and Initiatives
awd_abstract_narration:
The AGEP National Research Conference 2020 was created in response to the NSF's Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) program solicitation (NSF 16-552). The AGEP program seeks to advance knowledge about models to improve pathways to the professoriate and the successes of URM graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and faculty in specific STEM disciplines and/or STEM education research fields.  AGEP awardees develop, implement and study, via integrated educational and social science research, Alliance Models to transform the dissertator phase of doctoral education, postdoctoral training and/or faculty advancement, and the transitions within and across the pathway levels, of historically underrepresented minorities (URMs) in STEM and STEM education careers. 

As the nation addresses a STEM achievement gap between URM and non-URM undergraduate and graduate students, our universities and colleges struggle to recruit, retain and promote URM STEM faculty who serve as role models and academic leaders for URM students to learn from, work with and emulate. Recent NSF reports indicate that URM STEM associate and full professors occupy 8% of these senior faculty positions at all 4-year colleges and universities, and about 6% of these positions at the nation's most research-intensive institutions. This AGEP National Research Conference will advance knowledge about initiatives that can be sustained, institutionalized and scaled at US universities and colleges to advance URM graduate students, postdoctoral scholars and faculty in STEM and STEM education academic professions.

This conference convening will bring together hundreds of AGEP and non-AGEP awardees, as well as graduate students who are conducting relevant research. The goals of the conference are: (1) This conference will disseminate, adopt and adapt research findings, tools, and program resources generated by AGEP Alliances; (2) Participants will intentionally identify strategies within their institutional context that will position AGEP-funded projects for sustained impact and institutional change; and (3) Participants will engage in an innovative conference format that supports their learning, builds their connections to colleagues across the AGEP Alliance network, and creates a foundation from which they can take future action at their institution.

The two and half-day conference is scheduled for March of 2020, in Boston, MA. In addition to research panels, keynote addresses, and a poster session, there will be experiential learning sessions designed to advance knowledge about the institutionalization, sustainability and scaling of AGEP Alliance Models and their associated initiatives.  The proposed work includes both evaluation components and a dissemination plan for broader impacts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The AGEP 2020 conference was originally designed to be hosted as an in-person conference using a critical pedagogical grounding to foster new learning and high levels of engagement during the conference proceedings. In February of 2020, the conference organizers in collaboration with NSF made the call to postpone the conference due to the growing concern for what would eventually become an ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

The pandemic postponed the AGEP 2020 conference was split into two smaller scale, virtual conferences, one held in November of 2020 and the second in June of 2021. In the eight months leading up to the November conference, the conference planning team sought to maintain excitement and engagement with the AGEP community (all members of funded AGEP Alliance projects) by hosting a series of three webinars hosted monthly between July and September. These discussions were optional forms of engagement across alliances with the intention to implement a critical pedagogical webinar design that engaged alliance members in critical conversations to further define what the AGEP community stands for in a time of multiple pandemics (COVID-19 and anti-black racism) and how the community will show up for all membership, including and not limited to alliance key personnel, alliance programming participants, and all registered conference attendees. Live observations were recorded during the conference proceedings and a follow up survey was distributed to the conference attendees one day after the November conference was complete. 

The AGEP June 2021 Conference received an overall high satisfaction from its attendees. In particular, respondents highlighted the importance of having AGEP participants’ voices in the conference and expressed interest in continuing this type of engagement in the future events. Moreover, interactive workshops were considered more engaging compared to lecture-style presentations. In fact, the most engaging sessions were from alliances who submitted their outlines to us in advance, indicating that the conference design was successful in allowing more interactions. Furthermore, attendees expressed eagerness to have the next conference in-person, but at the same time were concerned about accessibility features in the in-person setting. These were likely addressed by the team planning the 2022 National Research Conference. 

We studied the systemic change approaches of 19 AGEP transformational alliances, drawing on organizational change theories in higher education reform and interpreting the landscape of AGEP alliances through mapping their theories of change, barriers to success, levels of change, and foci of change. Our research revealed that most alliances largely focused on the historically excluded STEM dissertators or postdocs, applying a social cognitive theory of change, even when they claimed to center institutional or cultural change. This implies that they believe that individuals, especially minoritized AGEP participants, need to change in order to be successful in academia. Such an approach needs to take care to avoid projecting a deficit mindset, or implying that AGEP participants, as a group, have ‘learning needs’ or that they are not fully prepared for the R1 research and faculty careers. This direct student support wrapped in a deficit mindset amplifies the need for cultural and institutional change.

 

 


Last Modified: 04/02/2023
Modified by: Sarah C Hokanson
